[AMD]
  • Installation
  • Examples
  • Try AMD
  • API
  • Source

An Automatic Matrix Differentiation Library

Examples

Supported Operations

AMD supports the following operations: 
+      : Binary Addition (infix)
-      : Binary Subtraction (infix)
*      : Binary Multiplication (infix)
/      : Binary Division (infix)
o      : Binary Element-wise Multiplication (infix)
'      : Unary Transpose (postfix)
_      : Unary Inverse (postfix)
+      : Unary Positive (prefix)
-      : Unary Negation (prefix)
tr()   : Trace (matrix function)
lgdt() : Log Determinant (matrix function)

Invalid Operations

The following operations are only valid when both operands are of the same type (i.e. both matrix or both scalar): 
+, -, o
The following operations are only valid on matrices: 
', tr(), lgdt()
The following operations return scalars: 
tr(), lgdt()
The following operations are only valid when both operands are of the same type (i.e. both matrix or both scalar): 
+, -, o
Therefore the following operation, for example, is invalid: 
tr(X) + X
This is invalid because we cannot add a scalar and a matrix.

Grammar

<Expr> = <Term>, { ("+"|"-"), <Term> };

<Term> = <InvTran>, { ("*"|"/"|"o"), <InvTran> };

<InvTran> = <Expr>, "'"  
          | <Expr>, "_"  
          | <Factor>;

<Factor> = <Literal>  
         | "(", <Expr>, ")"    
         | "-", <InvTran>  
         | "+", <InvTran>  
         | "tr(", <Expr>, ")"  
         | "lgdt(", <Expr>, ")";

<Literal> = ? uppercase character ?  
            | ? double ?

Grammar Key

This grammar is written using Extended Backus-Naur Form. The following is a table of important symbols and how they can be interpreted. 
=     : Definition
,     : Concatenation 
;     : Termination (end of rule)
|     : Alternation (can be at most one of the alternations in a group)
{...} : Repetition (can be repeated 0 or more times)
(...) : Grouping
"..." : Terminal string
?...? : Special sequence (e.g. integer, character)

Examples

Examples are shown with the input string on the left and the recursive rule matches on the right. 
A + B = <Expr>
      = <Term> + <Term>
      = <InvTran> + <InvTran>
      = <Factor> + <Factor>
      = <Literal> + <Literal>
      = ? uppercase character ? + ? uppercase character ?

tr(A'_) = <Expr> 
        = <Term>
        = <InvTran>
        = <Factor>
        = "tr(", <Expr>, ")"
        = "tr(", <Term>, ")"
        = "tr(", <InvTran>, ")"
        = "tr(", <Expr>, "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <Term>, "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <InvTran>, "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <Expr>, "'", "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <Term>, "'", "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <InvTran>, "'", "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <Factor>, "'", "_", ")"
        = "tr(", <Literal>, "'", "_", ")"
        = "tr(", ? uppercase character ? , "'", "_", ")"

C'+ tr(A*B) = <Expr>
            = <Term> + <Term>
            = <InvTran> + <InvTran>
            = <Expr>, "'" + <Factor>
            = <Term>, "'" + "tr(", <Expr>, ")"
            = <InvTran>, "'" + "tr(", <Term>, ")"
            = <Factor>, "'" + "tr(", <InvTran> * <InvTran>, ")" 
            = <Literal>, "'" + "tr(", <Factor> * <Factor>, ")"
            = ? uppercase character ?, "'" + "tr(", <Literal> * <Literal>, ")"
            = ? uppercase character ?, "'" + "tr(", ? uppercase character ? * ? uppercase character ?, ")"
Note: Though this expression would be parsed correctly by the parser, it would 
eventually fail the validation step when AMD detects that this expression is 
attempting to add a Matrix value to a Scalar value.
Please note that the current implementation of AMD only allows tr() and lgdt() as the outermost operation.
